questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue shows Hurthle cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre may be seen
  • Hurthle/ Askanazy cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45 - 65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with a history of fever and cough for 2 days. He is living with his wife who recently tested positive for COVID-19 and has been under home isolation. On examination, pulse is 110/min, BP is 78/58 mmHg, the temperature is 101.3 F, RR is 28 and SpO2 is 90%. Which of the following is not recommended in this patient’s management?
questions.solution:
Awake proning should be avoided in patients with hemodynamic instability. 

This patient can be classified to have moderate COVID-19 (SpO2 <94%, RR≥24). The management protocol for moderate COVID includes oxygen support, anticoagulation (LMWH/UFH), corticosteroids and antivirals. Awake proning may be used in moderate COVID in patients who continue to have hypoxia despite oxygen > 4L/min and no contraindications. As this patient is hypotensive and hemodynamically unstable, awake proning is not recommended.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

The Chi-square test is a non-parametric test of significance employed for two proportions using qualitative variables. It has the advantage of being of use when more than two groups are to be compared. It also offers information on the significance of any observed differences.

Tests of significance are used to check for significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of central tendency as the mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated for:
questions.solution:
Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated in Coronary Artery Disease prophylaxis like thromboembolism, however it is useful in certain cardiovascular disease.

Indication for HRT is as follows:

Therapeutic:

  • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency 
  • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents

Prophylactic:

  • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease and colonic cancer
  • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, 
  • menopause caused by radiotherapy, chemotherapy

Contraindications:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

Note:-

  • Not all women require HRT after menopause.
  • Besides, HRT does not suit all, and it may cause complications and be harmful.
  • However, it is logical to prescribe HRT and not withhold it when one needs it in the minimal effective dose for the shortest needed duration under supervision while on therapy.
  • Initially, every menopausal woman was advised to go on HRT as soon as menopause set in to be taken for several years.

Newer researches and their observations reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT, but 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle.

questions.text: Hernia with hydrocele is known as ________.
questions.solution:
Gibbon’s hernia is hernia with hydrocele.

Option b: Berger’s hernia is hernia into the pouch of Douglas.

Option c: Beclard’s hernia is femoral hernia through the opening of the saphenous vein.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the casualty with symptoms of sweating, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and yawning. On examination, mydriasis is present with elevated BP. On further questioning, the patient tells that he has not taken his usual dose of the drug for 3 days. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with the classic symptoms of heroin withdrawal.

Heroin withdrawal:

  • Characteristic symptoms: myalgia, arthralgia, abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and sweating.
  • Signs on physical examination: restlessness, elevated heart rate and blood pressure, pupillary dilatation (mydriasis), piloerection, and yawning.

Treatment for opioid dependence

Detoxification:

  • Long-acting opioid agonist: a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent the withdrawal symptoms.
  • Partial agonist: buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine: alpha-2 agonist acts as sympatholytic and reduces the withdrawal symptoms.

Maintenance:

  • Methadone, buprenorphine, LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol): opioid agonists which reduce craving.
  • Naltrexone: An opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, discourages per­sons with opioid dependence from substance seeking behavior.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows left-sided pneumothorax with the partial collapse of the left lung. Best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is PA view in full expiration.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of a pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax in a patient with bilateral pneumonia. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’).

questions.text: You see a middle-aged man presenting to the psychiatry OPD with the clinical features of speaking to himself, hearing two people talk about him, reduced affect, and impaired judgment which is present for more than 6 months. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has auditory hallucination, reduced affect, lack of insight, impaired judgment for more than 6 months, which makes the diagnosis of schizophrenia more likely.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM-5):

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the a, b, or c): 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6-month period may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as:

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behavior
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Note: DSM-5 does not require that delusions must be bizarre.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is not a physiological change of pregnancy.

Total T4 and T3 rise in the first trimester but the physiologically important free T4 and T3 levels remain unchanged. Hence, pregnant women remain euthyroid.

Option A: Normal pregnancy is characterized by mild fasting hypoglycemia, postprandial hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia.

Option B: By the 3rd trimester, there is an increase in the maternal basal metabolic rate by 10 to 20% in comparison to a nonpregnant woman.

Option D: The hypervolemia associated with normal pregnancy averages 40-45% above the nonpregnant blood volume after 32 to 34 weeks.

questions.text: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junction points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis.

It refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow. 

Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.

Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction before corrective surgery.

Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, the extrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, there is blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages.

Renal isotope scan ( DTPA or MAG-3 ) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of low mood for the past 2 weeks, reduced socialization, decreased appetite and inability to sleep for the past 3 months. She also complains of frequent backache and headache, with early morning awakening. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood for the past 2 weeks along with reduced appetite, reduced interest in socialization, somatic symptoms, and disturbed sleep, points towards a diagnosis of depression (major depressive disorder). 

The Diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are as follows:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. At least one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  • Depressed mood most of the day
  • Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  • Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  • Fatigue or loss of energy
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  • Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  • Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is assessed with an ECG during his wellness check-up visit. Calculate the heart rate from the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The RR interval has 19 small boxes in between, and hence the heart rate is 1500/19~79/min.

The relationship between the heart rate and the RR interval is given by: 

Heart rate = 1500/(number of small boxes (1mm each) in between successive R waves) 

Methods to calculate heart rate from ECG: 

Box counting methods: This can be done via the number of small boxes or the large boxes between two successive R waves. If using the large boxes, the equation is  

Heart rate = 300/(number of big boxes (5mm each) in between successive R waves) 

QRS counting methods: This is used when the heart rate is irregular. Thus there will be a variability in the RR intervals, making the box-counting method unreliable. Here, the number of QRS intervals in a set interval, for example, 10 seconds, is counted. This number is then multiplied by an appropriate factor to get an estimate for 60s. In this example, we would multiple the number of QRS complexes in 10s by 6. 

Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of more than 100 beats/minute and bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/minute.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman is admitted due to persistent vomiting. She gives a history of consuming food from outside. On evaluation, her blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings. What is the cause of her ABG findings?

pH - 7.52

HCO3 - 26 meq/L

PaCO2- 20 mmHg

Na - 123 mEq/L.

K - 3.2 mEq/L

Cl - 67 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient has hypovolemic, hypochloremic, hypokalemic, hyponatremic metabolic alkalosis with respiratory alkalosis. This is most probably due to persistent vomiting.

Inference from the given question stem:

Step 1: pH in this patient is 7.52 which is alkalemia.

Step 2: Bicarbonate level in this patient is 26 mEq/L which is increased. This signifies the presence of an excess of base. Hence, this is metabolic alkalosis.

Step 3: PaCO2 level in this patient is 20 mmHg, which is less than normal. This signifies respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4: Electrolyte imbalance - 

  • Na - 123 mEq/L signifies hyponatremia
  • K - 3.2 mEq/L signifies hypokalemia
  • Cl - 67 mEq/L signifies hypochloremia

Step 5: Volume depletion - Blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg signifies hypovolemia due to persistent vomiting.

Vomiting leads to loss of Hcl (acid) from the stomach resulting in metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia. This causes failure of secretion of HCO3- into the small intestine and HCO3- is added into the extracellular fluid. 

Increased level of HCO3- will be excreted in the urine making the urine alkaline with increased potassium and sodium excretion in the urine. This leads to hypokalemia and hyponatremia.

Other options:

Option A: Diabetic ketoacidosis is associated with high anion gap metabolic acidosis along with hyponatremia and hypochloremia. It may initially present with hyperkalemia.

Option C: Septic shock is characterized by high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Renal tubular acidosis is characterized by hyperchloremic, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 42-year old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presented with bouts of vomiting and stabbing pain in the epigastrium. He was binge drinking shortly before the symptoms started. He is febrile and tachycardic. The given findings were seen on bedside radiological imaging. Which among the following is a likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is suggestive of Pneumoperitoneum and the likely cause for this would be peptic ulcer perforation.

Gastric ulcers are more prone to perforate than bleed. Thus, these perforations lead to pneumoperitoneum which is an emergency and warrants immediate surgical intervention. 

The classical description of a patient with a perforated peptic ulcer is described in three stages:

Stage of peritonism: Initial 6 hours - patient presents with an acute burning epigastric pain with or without vomiting. Leakage of gastric acid into the peritoneal cavity causes diaphragmatic irritation which may lead to pain referred to the shoulder tip (Option D) and tracking of fluid in the right para-colic gutter may lead to right iliac fossa pain. Abdominal guarding with diminished abdominal movements on respiration is noted and the patient avoids movement to prevent pain. Tachycardia (Option B) is noted but pyrexia does not set in.
Stage of reaction: the symptoms temporarily subside due to the dilution of the exudate in the peritoneal cavity but abdominal rigidity remains (Option A).
Stage of diffuse peritonitis: sunken face, hollow cheeks, dry mucous membranes (facies hippocratica) with fever, tachycardia, low volume pulse and increasing abdominal distension.
Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Perforation is an indication for surgical exploration. Perforations less than 1 cm can be closed primarily with an omental patch repair, while larger perforations may require a distal gastrectomy with a roux-en-y reconstruction. Patients require prolonged PPI therapy postoperatively.

 Other options: 

A. Tension pneumothorax - presents with a rapid hemodynamic compromise with absent breath sounds. Pneumoperitoneum rarely is caused by pneumothorax, and downward displacement of air is more likely seen in retroperitoneal spaces.

C. Boerhaave syndrome or spontaneous esophageal rupture - occurs in alcoholics after binge drinking, due to forced vomiting from the closed glottis.  Pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema are seen here. 

D. Mallory Weis tear - longitudinal mucosal tear resulting in upper GI bleeding. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis of a patient with peripheral smear findings as shown below?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma. The peripheral smear given above shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells). This is characteristic of Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma.

Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma (CD4+):

  • It is observed in adults infected by human T cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1)
  • It is characterised by skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral blood lymphocytosis, and hypercalcemia.
  • Peripheral smear shows cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells)
  • A rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

questions.text: As a first-year dermatology resident, you see a patient with the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped, purple, polygonal, papules and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails are features of lichen planus.

Mucous membrane lesions are very common in lichen planus, occurring in almost 30–70% of cases. It is mostly seen on the tongue and buccal mucosa and also on the genitals and anal mucosa.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa are a characteristic feature and are known as Wickham’s striae.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility.  Her sonogram of both ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts is suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens most often as a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, oliguria.

Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity causes ascites and results in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentartion causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability.  

Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be seen associated with OHSS. 

Some of the risk factors for OHSS include:

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • Young age
  • High estradiol during ovulation induction
  • Pregnancy

Classification of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Grade I Abdominal discomfort or distension
Grade II

Grade I + nausea and vomiting /diarrhea.

  • Increased ovarian volume (>10 mL), or both

  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Multiple gestational preganancy
  • Fetal hydrops
  • Placentaomegaly

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Kallman syndrome -  hypothalamic hypogonadism is a cause of primary amenorrhea, not secondary. 

Primary amenorrhoea: is defined as an absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years. At age 13 years, if no menses have occurred and there is a complete absence of secondary sexual characteristics such as breast development, evaluation for primary amenorrhea should begin.. Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome), androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Turner syndrome present with primary amenorrhea. 

Kallman syndrome is associated with a low or absent GnRH. The condition is characterized by anosmia, hypogonadism, infertility, and absent, or partial pubertal maturation. Treatment includes GnRH, pituitary hormones, estrogen, and progestogen to induce menstruation.

Secondary amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses. Pregnancy is the most common cause of secondary amenorrhea. Sheehan's syndrome and Asherman's syndrome are other examples.

The flowcharts summarize the various causes of primary amenorrhea and the investigations undertaken for evaluation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presented with epistaxis. On clinical examination, the spleen was not palpable.  Her Hb=6 g/dL,  platelet count = 18,000/μL and white blood cell count is 3000/μL. questions.solution:
The clinical, laboratory, and bone marrow findings are diagnostic of aplastic anemia. The best method of management is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Aplastic anemia is pancytopenia with bone marrow hypocellularity. Patients will present with bleeding, anemia, and rarely infections.

Bone marrow biopsy will appear hypocellular with fat occupying the majority of the bone marrow.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the best method of management in young patients. Elderly patients and patients without an HLA matched donor are treated with antithymocyte globulin (ATG) in combination with cyclosporine.

The girl is suffering from Down’s syndrome and the most common cardiovascular lesion is an endocardial cushion defect.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with diarrhea, weight loss, and fever for  2 months. On endoscopy, ulcers are visualized with normal mucosa present in between ulcers. The rectum is spared. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 28-year-old man presents with a two-month history of diarrhoea, weight loss, and fever. Endoscopic examination reveals ulcers with areas of normal mucosa in between, and the rectum remains unaffected. These findings are indicative of Crohn's disease.

Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, but most commonly involves the terminal ileum and colon. It is characterized by transmural inflammation, which can lead to complications such as strictures, fistulas, and abscess formation. Symptoms include abdominal pain, persistent diarrhoea, weight loss, and fatigue. Patients may also experience extraintestinal manifestations such as arthritis, erythema nodosum, uveitis, and primary sclerosing cholangitis. The disease follows a relapsing-remitting course, with periods of flare-ups and remission.

The exact cause of Crohn’s disease remains unclear, but it is believed to result from a complex interplay between genetic predisposition, immune system dysregulation, and environmental triggers such as diet, smoking, and gut microbiota imbalance. Diagnosis is made through a combination of clinical presentation, endoscopy with biopsy, imaging studies, and laboratory markers like faecal calprotectin and C-reactive protein. Treatment aims to control inflammation, relieve symptoms, and prevent complications. This includes medications such as aminosalicylates, corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and biologic therapies targeting tumour necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) or integrins. In severe cases, surgical intervention may be required, but recurrence after surgery is common. Long-term management involves dietary modifications, smoking cessation, and regular monitoring to reduce disease progression and complications.

questions.text: The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the:
questions.solution:
The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome. 

The Y chromosome has a sex determining region called the SRY gene (Sex-determining Region of the Y chromosome). If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called Testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH), a peptide hormone, that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

In absence of the Y chromosome and the SRY gene consequently, the gonads will develop as ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the fallopian tubes and the upper part of the vagina.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of excessive fatigue and palpitations. On examination, severe pallor and pedal edema are present with an oxygen saturation of 89%. Her hemoglobin is 5.9 g/dL. Which among the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient is packed cell transfusion.

The treatment of choice for anemia with hemoglobin between 5-7 g/dL at < 34 weeks period of gestation with hypoxia and an impending sign of heart failure like pedal edema is packed cell transfusion. Only packed cell transfusions are carried out and about 80 mL-100 mL of blood is infused at a time and repeated only after 24 hours. 

The following precautions are taken prior to blood transfusions:

  • Administration of antihistaminics intramuscularly
  • Administration of diuretics intramuscularly at least 2 hours prior to transfusion to produce negative fluid balance
  • Adjustment of the drip rate to 10 drops/minute
  • Observation of the pulse, respiration, and basal lung crepitations. 

The complications of blood transfusions include premature labor, increased chances of worsening cardiac failure, and transfusion reactions.

Following are the RCOG guidelines for initiating blood transfusion during pregnancy:

  • Antepartum period
    1. Pregnancy < 34 weeks:
      1. Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
    2. Pregnancy > 34 weeks:
      1. Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Severe anemia with decompensation
    3. Anemia not due to hematinic deficiency:
      1. Hemoglobinopathy or bone marrow failure syndromes
      2. Consult hematologist
    4. Acute hemorrhage:
      1. Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
      2. If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing hemorrhage
  • Intrapartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. The decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms
  • Postpartum period
    1. Hb <7g%
    2. Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability.

Other options given are parenteral formulations of iron therapy that are not indicated according to the criteria given above. Parenteral iron therapy is indicated in the following conditions:

  •  Contraindications of oral therapy such as severe gastrointestinal side effects of taking oral iron (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, teeth staining, epigastric distress)
  •  Non-cooperative patient 
  •  Cases that are seen for the first time during the last 8–10 weeks with severe anemia.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to you by his parents as they are worried that he is not growing. On assessment, his height and weight are normal for his age. To assess puberty, what is the first sign you would look for?
questions.solution:
The first sign of puberty in males is the increase in testicular volume.

In males at 11 to 12 years, the growth of the testis (>4 mL in volume) and thinning of the scrotum occurs, which are the first signs of puberty. This is followed by the pigmentation of the scrotum, growth of the penis, and by pubarche.
Growth of testis > pubarche > adrenarche > growth spurt (TPAG).

In females at 10 to 11 years, the breast bud (thelarche) appears, which is the first sign of puberty followed by the appearance of pubic hair (pubarche), growth spurt, and menarche. 
Thelarche > pubarche > growth spurt > menarche (TPGM).

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score?
questions.solution:
The woman has had two pregnancies in total - the previous twin pregnancy and the current pregnancy, with the first pregnancy resulting in delivery at term. Hence, her obstetric score would be G2P1 (Gravida - 2, Para - 1). 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
  • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages
  • L - Living children.

Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins for the first time is expressed as primipara.

The GTPAL system includes the following:

  • Gravida
  • Term (>37 weeks)
  • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
  • Abortions (<20 weeks)
  • Number of living children

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the technique of interrupted Sutures. Here each suture should reach into the depths of the wound and be placed at right angles to the axis of the wound.

Option B: Mattress suture produce an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially when the edges to be anastomosed are irregular. questions.text: What is the most common serious complication expected to occur in patients with hernia?
questions.solution:
Strangulation is the most common serious complication of a hernia. 

An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia can lead to a bowel obstruction or strangulation. Obstruction is characterized by colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal distension and obstipation. Features of obstruction along with vascular compromise is seen in strangluation. Strangulation occurs in 1% to 3% of groin hernias. It is more common at the extremes of life.

Most strangulated hernias are indirect inguinal hernias. However, femoral hernias have the highest rate of strangulation (15% to 20%) of all hernias, and it is, therefore, recommended that all femoral hernias be repaired at the time of discovery. Tenderness is the first sign of strangulation.

The first step is the correction of hypovolemia. The treatment of choice is immediate surgery. The fundus is opened first during surgery.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of peripheral occlusive vascular disease?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittent claudication. 

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day to day. The muscle group affected is one anatomical level below the arterial disease.

Boyd’s classification :

Class l - Pain on walking but pain decreases on continuation of walking.

Class ll - Pain on walking, but continues to walk despite the pain.

Class lll - Pain forces the patient to stop walking.

Class lV - Pain at rest.

It is worsened by health conditions such as anaemia and heart failure.

Other options :

Option A: Rest pain is when the disease progresses to a degree that perfusion is severely reduced and cramp-like pain in the calf is felt even at rest. 

Option C: Severe arterial insufficiency leads to tissue ulceration and gangrene.

Option D: A swollen and erythematous limb is seen in critical limb ischemia. When the limb is in the dependent position, there is pooling of blood which causes the limb to appear red and swollen(sunset foot sign).

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents with spotting PV, hyperemesis, and lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. USG done is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and USG showing snowstorm appearance is suggestive of a complete hydatidiform mole. 

The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces. Fetus and amniotic sac are absent. 

Investigations for molar pregnancy are:

questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient will be 3. The lowest possible Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 3 and never zero.

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

questions.text: An​ 8-year-old child had an unprovoked dog bite. Which of the following measures should be taken?

choices.text: Withhold the vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days
Kill the dog and send brain for biopsy

questions.solution:
It is appropriate to give post-exposure prophylaxis immediately to reduce the chances of getting rabies by administering cell culture derived vaccine.

Zero by 30 : is the Global strategic plan to end human death from dog mediated rabies by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins (WHO guidelines)

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, GOI:

Individuals with WHO category II or III exposures should receive PEP without delay.

One ID dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one IM dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • RIG provides a passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight.
  • WHO has recommended the use of Monoclonal Antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against RABV, as alternatives for RIGs in PEP.
  • All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration. Rabies immunoglobulin may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.
  • Prioritization of RIG allocation: Multiple bites>Deep wounds>Bites to head, neck, and hands>Patients with severe immunodeficiency>The biting animal is confirmed or probable rabies>Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

(PrEP)Pre-exposure prophylaxis

  • PrEP considered in remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult, the dog bite incidence is >5% per year or vampire bat rabies are known to be present.
  • Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of three intramuscular (IM) or intradermal (ID) doses are given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. For adults, the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm; for young children (under 1 year of age), the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended. Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.
  • For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous complete PrEP or PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:
    • Proper wound management should be done.
    • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
    • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.
    Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP or PrEP within the last three months.
    • People who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccine of unproven potency or cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment should be treated as a fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.text: A multigravida who had normal vaginal delivery develops PPH. The third stage was managed actively and placenta and membranes were expelled completely. What is the first step in management?

choices.text: Insert two 16G cannulas and start IV fluids
Palpate the uterus to determine its consistency

questions.solution:
The first step in management is to insert two 16G cannulas and start IV fluids.

  • Whenever there is excessive blood loss in a pregnant woman, steps are simultaneously taken to identify the source of bleeding and to begin resuscitation.
  • If she is postpartum it is essential to identify the cause for the PPH and at least 1 and preferably more large-bore IV infusion systems are established promptly with rapid administration of crystalloid solutions while blood is made available.

questions.text: A 27-year-old sexually active male develops an erythematous vesicular lesion on the lips within hours after taking a drug. The lesion healed with hyperpigmentation. The most common drug or drug class implicated is ______.
questions.solution:
The characteristic lesion healing with hyperpigmentation following drug intake is consistent with fixed drug eruption. 

  • Fixed drug eruption (FDE) is a cutaneous adverse drug reaction (delayed type hypersensitivity) characterized by recurrent well‐defined lesions occurring at the same sites each time the offending drug is taken.
  • It typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.
  • The most common drugs that act as triggers are:
    • NSAIDs (25%)
    • Paracetamol (15%)
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Tetracyclines
  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and oedematous plaque, which evolves to become dusky, violaceous, and occasionally vesicular or bullous lesion. Lesions are usually solitary or few in number.
  • Commonly affected sites include the lips, genitals (most common), palms, and soles; 5% of cases may have an exclusive mucosal involvement.
  • Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported:
    • NSAID‐induced FDE affecting the genitals and lips
    • Tetracycline and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole‐induced FDE affecting the genitals
  • The majority of FDE is self‐limiting with an excellent prognosis.

questions.text: A neonate was brought to the pediatrician on day 5 of life with bilious vomiting and failure to pass meconium. On examination, the abdomen was distended. and  X-Ray showed distended bowel loops. Due to suggestive family history, the resident suspected Hirschsprung's disease. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.

It shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining)

 Anorectal manometry is an important screening tool. It shows the absence of rectoanal inhibitory reflex.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the hospital. He is found to have a sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control. No confusion is reported after regaining consciousness. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern (as shown below). Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures. 

Option A: Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control.

Option B: Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking movement involving the entire body or a part of it.

Option D: Generalised tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by post-ictal confusion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of greenish discharge from the nipple for the past 1 month. Personal history is significant for cigarette smoking. On compression of her breast, greenish discharge from multiple ducts was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia. 

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula or nipple retraction.

  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is duct carcinoma.
  • The most common cause of serous discharge from the breast is fibrocystic disease of breast.

questions.text: A toddler presented to ER with complaints of fever, drooling, and a muffled voice since evening. On examination, the he has a stridor and you pick up a "thumb sign" on the lateral x-ray of his neck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Thumb sign on lateral x-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis (AE). It is seen due to epiglottic enlargement.

AE is an inflammation of the epiglottis. The arytenoids, false cords, and posterior tongue may also be involved.

In children, Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is the most common cause. This has decreased dramatically since the widespread availability of immunization (pentavalent). Streptococcus pyogenes, S. pneumoniae, and S. aureus have also been implicated. Non-infectious causes can be foreign body ingestion and trauma from thermal or caustic agents.

It has a progressive and potentially fulminating course, characterised by high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.

AE is a clinical diagnosis and a true emergency, X-ray soft tissue neck is not necessary to confirm it.  It may be used to rule out differentials such as laryngotracheobronchitis, foreign body obstruction, retropharyngeal abscess or congenital anomalies. The time taken for X-rays should be avoided in a critically ill child due to the risk of sudden complete airway obstruction.

The definitive diagnosis of AE is made during direct laryngoscopy. However, since manipulation can induce a laryngospasm, it is generally avoided.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable. Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the next best step is to explore surgically.

Etiology and risk factors- 

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis(like a clapper in a bell). Most common cause.
  • Inversion of the testis.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are - scrotal pain and swelling, erythema, negative cremasteric reflex, nausea, and vomiting, testis seems high in the scrotum and twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

Management is determined primarily on clinical grounds. Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false-positives are high and hence not routinely recommended. Urgent scrotal exploration is indicated if there is doubt regarding the diagnosis. A transverse scrotal incision is taken and if the testis is viable twisting again is prevented by fixation with three non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea of the testis and the scrotal raphe.

Differential diagnosis -

  • Epididymo-orchitis - Here dysuria associated with the accompanying urinary infection is commonly present. In epididymo-orchitis elevation of the testis reduces the pain while it makes it worse in torsion. 
  • Torsion of a testicular appendage - Here the most common structure to twist is the appendix of the testis and it can be visible as a small dark spot. In most cases, it is indistinguishable from torsion testis. Hence in cases of doubt surgical exploration is done.

questions.text: The drug of choice for the treatment of acute adrenal insufficiency in a patient with previously known adrenal insufficiency  is
questions.solution:
For acute adrenal insufficiency patients with a previously known diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone would be the drug of choice.

Other options:

However, in a patient without a previous diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays needed to diagnose adrenal insufficiency, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol assays.

Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies:

 Rehydration

  • Usually carried out by saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 l/h supported by continuous cardiac monitoring

Glucocorticoid replacement

  • Should be initiated by a bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the administration of 100–200 mg hydrocortisone for over 24 h.

Mineralocorticoid replacement

  • Can be initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg because at higher doses hydrocortisone provides sufficient stimulation of the mineralocorticoid receptors

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a history of fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found in his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient would be infective endocarditis.

Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:

  • Roth spots: These are are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
  • Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles.

questions.text: A child is born with the following feature. What advice do you give to the mother, with regard to the next pregnancy?

choices.text: 400 mcg of folic acid after confirmation of pregnancy

questions.solution:
The given image shows spina bifida, a most common neural tube defect (NTD) in the child; 4000 mcg of folic acid periconceptionally is given to prevent NTDs in the next child.

Normal dose of folic acid in a pregancy is 400 mcg (0.4 mg). However, a previous child with NTD significantly increases the risk of an NTD in the next pregnancies. An increased dose of folic acid is needed to prevent NTD in the next child. Hence, 4000 mcg (4 mg) of folic acid is advised daily in the periconceptional period (because nervous system development occurs in early periods of gestation).

questions.text: The method shown in the image is:

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman at 10 week of gestation comes to the clinic for a check-up following an MTP. On ultrasound, retained tissue was found and the following instrument was used for its removal. What is this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.

Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation . 

The indications of this procedure are given as follows:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
  • Molar pregnancy

questions.text: The cystographic appearance shown below is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Christmas tree bladder or pine cone bladder is a cystogram appearance which usually seen in severe neurogenic bladder with increased sphincter tone.

  • A pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder is a cystogram appearance in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall.
  • It is typically seen in (detrusor sphincter dyssynergia) due to suprasacral lesions (above S2-S4) or epiconal lesions (in and around S2-S4).
  • Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.
  • This finding is not pathognomonic of a neurogenic bladder. It can also be seen in patients with lesions anywhere along the sacral reflex arc. Occasionally, it is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

questions.text: Menopause is defined as cessation of menses for a period of _____.
questions.solution: Menopause is defined as cessation of ovarian function for 12 months resulting in permanent amenorrhoea. It is a retrospective diagnosis.

questions.text: The most common cause of short stature is:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of short stature is constitutional growth delay. 

Characteristics of constitutional growth delay:

  • Normal length and weight at birth
  • Appropriate growth for the first 6-12 months of age
  • A deceleration in growth after the initial normal period
  • Height and weight fall below the 3rd percentile for age
  • Resumes normal height velocity by 3 years
  • Puberty is also delayed
  • Bone age lower than chronological age
  • History of delayed growth spurt or puberty in one or both parents

questions.text: During rounds, you have been asked to examine a patient with an ulcer over the face. Which of the following features will raise the suspicion of it being a squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
On examination of an ulcer, everted margins will be suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. Variants of SCC in-situ include:

  • Bowen's disease
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Cautery ablation
  • Cryotherapy
  • Drug therapy including imiquimod
  • Moh’s microsurgery
  • Radiation therapy

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of lung cancer is brought in by his family with progressive fatigue and confusion. He complains of nausea, abdominal pain, and constipation. Blood tests show hypercalcemia. Which of the following type of lung cancer is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The primary cause of his symptoms is the ectopic production of PTH-related peptide which leads to hypercalcemia, mainly associated with squamous cell carcinoma.

The patient shows signs and symptoms for hypercalcemia which is the most common life-threatening metabolic complication seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Hyponatremia secondary to SIADH is also seen associated with lung cancer. However, they can be usually managed through fluid restriction alone and resolve within 1-4 weeks after initiating chemotherapy.

questions.text: A man presented with bleeding per rectum which he noticed after passing stools for the past 2 weeks. On straining, a reddish mass as shown in the image was seen protruding out of the anal canal. It did not reduce spontaneously and had to be manually reduced. What is the grade of hemorrhoids in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, as the prolapsed haemorrhoids required manual reduction, it is suggestive of third-degree haemorrhoids.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause?
questions.solution:
Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

Postmenopausal bleeding is defined as bleeding from the genital tract, more than 12 months after the last menstrual period in a woman not on hormone replacement. All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial malignancy since age is a significant risk factor for this.

Transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) is a better first-line investigation since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer.

Endometrial sampling is indicated if:

  • The endometrial thickness is >4 mm
  • The endometrium shows diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity)
  • The endometrium is not adequately visualized on transvaginal sonography
  • The woman has persistent bleeding, as it can be a sign of endometrial cancer even when the endometrial thickness is less than 4mm.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

 

Other options:

Option A: Pap smear should be offered to all women above the age of 21 years who are sexually active for at least 3 years. Colposcopic examination and selective biopsy are considered in patients with abnormal Pap smears.

Option B: Visual inspection with iodine is done where the facilities for Pap screening do not exist. This involves painting the cervix with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the cervix and vagina, such as in cases of carcinoma cervix.

The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen, therefore stains mahogany brown on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.

Option C: The colposcopic study is challenging in postmenopausal women because of narrow vaginas, senile vaginitis, indrawn and poorly visible squamocolumnar junction, and atrophic cervix.

questions.text: All of the following are the features of Kawasaki disease except:
questions.solution:
Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: Which organism is the leading cause of meningitis in AIDS?
questions.solution:
Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.            

Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of Cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination(CrAg).

Primary Prophylaxis - Oral Fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a chronic history of early satiety and recurrent non-bilious vomiting after heavy meals. Barium meal revealed a diffusely narrowed second portion of the duodenum, suggesting extrinsic compression. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental anomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not an MRCP.

The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.

It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome.

Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates. 

Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas.

The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the hospital with fever, malaise, and arthralgia for a 1-month duration. She also complains of pain, numbness, and weakness in her right arm which has been increasing over the past 1 week. Clinical examination reveals weak radial pulses and her lab investigations show elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features with marked weakening of pulse in the upper extremities and laboratory findings of elevated ESR are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It is also known as pulseless disease. 

Takayasu arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis that commonly affects adolescents or young females. It has a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches. Depending on the artery occluded, patients present with the following symptoms:

  • Subclavian artery (most common) - pain, numbness, claudication, and weak radial pulses on the affected side.
  • Common carotid artery - visual symptoms, syncope, and stroke.
  • Renal artery - hypertension and renal failure.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents to the ER with symptoms suggestive of myxedema coma. Which of the following conditions is least likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is least likely in this patient. Clinical manifestations of myxedema coma include decreased consciousness, seizures and hypothermia. The temperature may be as low as 23 oC.

Hypoventilation leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia plays a major role in myxedema pathogenesis. Hypoglycemia and dilutional hyponatremia are also attributed to the development of symptoms.

Myxedema coma is a serious condition with a mortality rate of 20-40%. Interestingly, the clinical outcomes are independent of the detected T4 and TSH levels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents 3 days after an episode of unprotected intercourse. He complains of profuse purulent discharge per urethra and severe burning pain on passing urine. Which of the following is a probable diagnosis?

questions.text: You are treating a college student for acne. While examining him, you observe the following finding. What initial treatment will you recommend for this finding?

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is a caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.

  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with the complaints of mass per vagina, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During a pre-anesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended in her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of severe uterine prolapse in elderly women. Le Fort’s repair is recommended in this case.

This repair is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • Very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse
  • Do not wish to retain sexual function
  • Medically unfit for major surgeries

This procedure can be performed under sedation and local anesthesia, or epidural anesthesia. The vaginal flaps from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised, the raw areas are apposed in the midline with catgut sutures. This prevents the uterus from prolapsing.

This operation limits marital functions; hence, it should not be advised in women who wish to retain sexual function.

Other options

Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Sling operations are best suited to nulliparous prolapse. It includes,

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy (Option A) 
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation (Option B) 
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation (Option D)

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the casualty after he was found lying near a ditch. He had a laceration over his scalp. His GCS on arrival was 13 and after a few minutes, it dropped to 10. A plain CT scan was done and given below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan showing a concavo-convex shaped hematoma on the left side with a midline shift to the right is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses.

The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands.

Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following maximally affect the positive predictive value of a test?
questions.solution:
Positive predictive value (PPV) is maximally affected by the prevalence of the disease.

If the prevalence of a disease in a population is high, the high will be the positive predictive value of a screening test, and the more accurate will be the test. If the prevalence declines, the PPV will be low.

PPV is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. It is affected the most by prevalence. However, both sensitivity and specificity can change the predictive value.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came to the hospital with the following complaints as shown in the image below. She noticed that these nail changes started appearing 2 months ago. There is no significant occupation history. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing nail pitting and salmon patches in fingernails are characteristic of nail psoriasis.

  • Nail pitting is the most frequent sign.
  • Subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch is a highly specific sign seen in psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discolouration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.
  • Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time.
  • Nail pitting/ thimble pits are formed due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

A) Onychomycosis:

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many fungi may be causative.

Clinical features : A yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

B) Arsenic poisoning:

Mee’s lines are seen in nails in arsenic poisoning. Mees lines (Transverse leukonychia) are single or multiple white transverse bands, in the arcuate form of the lunula. They reflect a systemic disorder like arsenic poisoning, thallium poisoning, chemotherapy, or septicemia. The pathology is in the nail matrix.

D) Lichen planus:

It is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes, often with a chronic course with relapses and periods of remission.

Nail involvement occurs in up to 10% of cases, majority cases present during the fifth or sixth decades. Fingernails are affected more frequently than toenails. The most common changes are exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A patient suspected of tubal pregnancy undergoes a transvaginal ultrasound, which is inconclusive. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Serum Beta hCG levels are the investigation to be performed if TVS is inconclusive. It confirms that a pregnancy is present.

Tubal pregnancy, a type of ectopic pregnancy, occurs when a fertilized egg implants in the fallopian tube instead of the uterus. It is a life-threatening condition that can lead to tubal rupture and severe internal bleeding if untreated. Beta-hCG levels play a crucial role in diagnosis, as they typically rise more slowly than in a normal intrauterine pregnancy.

In a normal pregnancy, beta-hCG levels double every 48 hours, whereas in an ectopic pregnancy, they often rise abnormally or plateau. A beta-hCG level of ≥1500–2000 mIU/mL without an intrauterine gestational sac on ultrasound strongly suggests ectopic pregnancy.

Serial beta-hCG monitoring helps guide management, which may include medical treatment with methotrexate or surgical intervention if rupture occurs. Symptoms include pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, and dizziness, especially if rupture leads to hemorrhagic shock. Early detection and prompt treatment are essential to prevent complications and preserve fertility.

Levels, if greater than 1500 IU/L, tell us that there is some problem with the pregnancy such as:

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Dead fetus
  • Miscarriage

Note: Serum beta HCG can detect a pregnancy as early as 5 days before the first missed period.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first line drug of choice in a patient with myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Pyridostigmine is the first-line drug of choice in the treatment of symptomatic myasthenia gravis.

Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine.
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment.
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with recurrent headaches. MRI shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Coronal T1 MRI shows a solid, well-defined, and extra-axial tumor. It involves the mid falx cerebri, and is seen as a spontaneously hyperintense and homogeneously enhanced mass in the midline, arising from falx. These features are suggestive of meningioma.

Meningiomas are extra-axial tumors (lesions that are outside of brain parenchyma). They are a non-glial neoplasm that originates from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges and are located anywhere that meninges are found. They are associated with NF-2 gene mutation.

Meningioma shows female predominance that may be related to the fact that some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors.

Typical meningiomas appear as dural-based masses isointense to gray matter on both T1 and T2 weighted imaging and demonstrate vivid contrast enhancement on both MRI and CT.

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

  • CSF vascular cleft sign indicates that the mass is extra-axial. There is a cleft between the tumor and normal brain parenchyma. The image below is a diagrammatic representation of this sign:

 

  • Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement of the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based. The image is coronal T1W spin-echo MRI of the brain with contrast enhancement showinging dural tail (arrow) in meningioma (arrowhead).

questions.text: The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly rotated to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.
