questions.text: A lady at 14 weeks of gestation presents with abdominal pain and persistent browny vaginal discharge for a few days. On examination, the uterus appears smaller than the period of gestation with a closed cervical os. Doppler ultrasound reveals non-audibility of the fetal heart sound which was audible before. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman with 14 weeks of gestation presenting with abdominal pain, persistent browny vaginal discharge, smaller uterus for gestation, closed cervical os, non-audibility of the fetal heart sound in ultrasound is suggestive of missed miscarriage.

Missed miscarriage or early fetal demise is termed when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period.

Patients usually present with features of threatened miscarriage like dull pain or bleeding per vaginum followed by:

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • The uterus appears smaller in size (cessation of uterine growth)
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Closed cervical os
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac in real-time ultrasonography

Beyond 12 weeks, the retained fetus in the uterus becomes macerated and mummified. 

The expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival is termed abortion.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A- Inevitable miscarriage is the type of abortion where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

Option C- Threatened miscarriage is the type of abortion where the process of miscarriage has started but in a state from which recovery is possible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • The uterus and cervix feel soft
  • On ultrasound:
    • Well-formed gestation ring
    • Presence of fetal cardiac motion 

Option D- Complete miscarriage is termed when products of conception are expelled en masse.

Features:

  • Abdominal pain subsides
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • The uterus is smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • Ultrasound shows an empty uterine cavity

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with severe pancreatitis. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe hypoxia. Below is the CXR obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of severe pancreatitis and the chest X-ray findings of B/L diffuse alveolar opacities are suggestive of ARDS.

Severe pancreatitis gives rise to inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS. 

CXR features in ARDS:

  • Early findings include normal or diffuse alveolar opacities (consolidation), which are often bilateral and which obscure the pulmonary vascular markings.
  • Later, these opacities progress to more extensive consolidation that is diffuse.

Prolonged bed rest increases the risk of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. However, the CXR shows diffuse alveolar opacities making the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia usually appears after 48 hours of admission. Areas of consolidation in unilateral or bilateral lung fields may be seen depending on severity. 

Left ventricular failure is an important differential diagnosis for ARDS. However, the patient's history of acute pancreatitis makes the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is brought to the ER with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose of 520 mg/dl and urine positive for ketone bodies. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for controlling hyperglycemia in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is short-acting insulin, preferably regular insulin.

Intermediate (such as lente insulin and NPH), long-acting insulins, and oral hypoglycemic agents are never used in the initial management of DKA. 

The mainstay of treatment is the administration of normal saline followed by infusion of short-acting insulin. The precipitating event must be identified and treated. Careful monitoring of K+ levels and replacement in the later stages is required, as insulin therapy causes hypokalemia.

questions.text: A person presents with complaints of numbness, tingling and paresthesias of the thumb, index finger and middle finger. There is numbness at the dorsum of the base of the thumb as well. What structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Patient presents with pain and paresthesia over the lateral 3 and a half digits and numbness at the dorsum of the base of the thumb, both of which are indicative of a median nerve injury.

There may be weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted. Carpal tunnel syndrome is a common cause and can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

Median nerve injuries:

Distal injury: Thus an injury to the distal median nerve affects the 1st and 2nd lumbricals sparing the flexor digitorum profundus. This causes hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints, involving the index and middle fingers. This attitude of the hand known as the median claw hand may be seen at rest and is more pronounced on attempting to extend the fingers (attitude is similar to proximal ulnar injury).

Proximal injury: Since the opposing flexor digitorum profundus of the 2nd and 3rd digit that causes the clawing is also affected, the clawing of the hand is less pronounced in distal injuries of the ulnar nerve. The deficits present during voluntary flexion of the digits. Thus, on attempting to make a fist, the flexion of the 2nd and 3rd digits is affected while the 4th and 5th digits are normal giving the Benediction hand sign.

In both cases of median nerve palsy, there is loss of sensations on lateral 3½ digits including the nail beds and distal phalanges on the dorsum of the hand.

Tinel's sign is positive where percussing over the median nerve reproduces symptoms. Phalen's test is positive where the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion with the dorsum of the hands pressed together.

Other Options: 

Option A: Injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. It results in the loss of function of both flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS). Hence, the index finger sticks out when the patient is asked to clasp their hand. 

Option B: In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

Option C:  In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with 'wrist drop' in case of paralyzed wrist extensors, and 'finger drop' when extensor digitorum is paralyzed. When there is compression in the axilla, radial nerve palsy is called Saturday night palsy. There is paralysis of the triceps, and weakness of the wrist and hand. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with long-standing complaints of dysphagia which was getting worse for the past 4 months. A barium swallow was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is the definitive treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient likely has achalasia cardia and the definitive treatment is Heller's myotomy. Surgical management is the first-line treatment modality. 

Achalasia or 'failure to relax' in Greek occurs due to the lack of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus (Auerbach's). The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax leading to dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and progressive dilation of the esophagus proximal to the constriction. 

Barium radiology shows hold-up in the distal esophagus, abnormal contractions in the oesophageal body, and a tapering stricture in the distal esophagus often described as a ‘bird’s beak’.

Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the procedure of choice. Here, the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia are cut. However, this can cause iatrogenic gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) due to damage to the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Thus, newer techniques involve a partial fundoplication like Dor's procedure to reinforce the sphincter and reduce GERD symptoms. 

Endoscopic myotomy is a newer, alternate procedure. Here, a submucosal tunnel is formed in the mid esophagus region that allows a long myotomy. 

Option A: Calcium channel blockers can be given in the initial stages of the disease. They relieve the chest pressure that occurs around mealtimes. However, they are not permanent treatments and can be used while waiting for surgery.  

Option B: Botulinum toxin injection can be used as a treatment in patients who may not be candidates for surgery or dilatation. Limitations to botulinum toxin injections are that the effect is short-lived (6-12 months) and patients often require multiple treatments.

Option C: Pneumatic dilatation of the LES has is successful in 75% of patients. It involves using a balloon to stretch the LES and improve competence. It requires multiple sessions and has a low risk of esophageal perforation.

questions.text: Transplant of an organ/tissue from mother to child is an example of:

Isograft  is the transfer of cells/tissues/organs are transplanted from a donor to a genetically identical recipient. (monozygotic twins)

Autograft is the transfer of tissue from one location to another location on the same patient.

questions.text: Project MONICA was managed under:
questions.solution:
WHO has completed a project known as MONICA, it is related to cardiovascular diseases. It stands for the multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. It was done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in different countries. 26 countries were participating in this project, which was planned to continue for a 10 year period ending in 1994.

This project specifically focussed on trends in event rates for coronary heart attacks and strokes, and on trends in cardiovascular risk factors ( blood pressure, cigarette smoking and serum cholesterol) in men and women aged 25-64 in the same defined communities.

The WHO MONICA project has without any doubt significantly contributed to global prevention efforts. The MONICA methodology is increasingly used as a measurement tool for cardiovascular and non-communicable disease prevention and control programs.

questions.text: Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved, like the number of lives saved, instead of monetary benefit is called ______________
questions.solution:
Cost-effective analysis: The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the application in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. However, even cost-effective analysis is not possible in many cases.

other options:

Cost-benefit analysis: The economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given program is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits in the health field, as a result of a particular program, cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. We generally express the benefit in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Input-output analysis: How much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, "input" refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials and time); and "output" refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty ward with high fever and pain abdomen.  He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of severe colonic inflammation, most commonly associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like ulcerative colitis and infectious colitis such as Clostridium difficile infection. It is characterized by rapid and extreme dilation of the colon, systemic toxicity, and a high risk of perforation. Symptoms include severe abdominal pain, distension, fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status, often progressing rapidly.

Management involves aggressive medical treatment with bowel rest, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and corticosteroids if associated with inflammatory bowel disease. If there is no improvement or if perforation occurs, emergent colectomy is required to prevent sepsis and death. Early recognition and intervention are crucial for improving outcomes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the OPD by his wife for gasping episodes during sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness. She reported that he even dozed off while driving yesterday and nearly caused an accident. He is being treated for hypertension, gastro-oesophageal reflux, and type 2 diabetes. What else would be the ideal therapy for his symptoms?

choices.text: Implantable neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS). The ideal therapy is continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP).

Option A: Supplemental oxygenation can improve oxygen saturation but there is little evidence that it improves OSAHS symptoms.

Option B: Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is the most common surgery done in OSAHS but it is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

Option D: Unilateral neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve through a surgically implanted device is a recently tested therapy for OSAHS. It can be used as an alternative in selected patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

The FDA recently authorized eXciteOSA, a new prescription-only device to reduce snoring & mild obstructive sleep apnea. This is the first device used while awake that is intended to improve tongue muscle function, which in time helps prevent the tongue from collapsing backwards and obstructing the airway during sleep.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presented with cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth. The tongue is slightly pushed to the right side. He also complains of pain off and on. He is likely to be suffering from _______
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests ranula.

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that takes on the appearance of a ‘frog’s belly’. Ranula is derived from ‘Rana’, the Latin for frog.

A ranula can resolve spontaneously, but many also require active treatment. The traditional and effective way is to remove the sublingual gland, but it is not an easy operation and the morbidity can be significant.

Other options:

  • Ectopic thyroid: It is a cystic condition. Usually painless. Presents in the midline and will be at the base of the tongue and not on the floor of the mouth.
  • Cystic hygroma: It’s a disease of neonates and early childhood, hence it can be excluded.
  • Vincent’s angina: It is a bilateral condition with a picture of cellulitis. Cysts are not present.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient comes with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia is seen in Weber’s syndrome.

Weber’s syndrome occurs due to infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the PCA. It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, and damages III cranial nerve and the pyramidal fibers. It results in contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy.

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of:

Based on PFTs, lung disorders are broadly classified into:

  • Obstructive lung disease (OLD)
  • Restrictive lung disease (RLD)
  • Pulmonary vascular disease

FEV1/FVC represents the proportion of a person's vital capacity they are able to expire in the first second of forced expiration (FEV1) to the full, forced vital capacity (FVC). In obstructive lung disease, FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in 1 second) is greatly decreased compared to FVC (Forced Vital Capacity) due to the obstruction of airways during expiration. 

Because of damage to the lungs or narrowing of the airways inside the lungs, people with OLD have difficulty exhaling all the air from the lungs, and the exhaled air comes out more slowly than normal (greatly decreased FEV1). At the end of a full exhalation, an abnormally high amount of air may still linger in the lungs(Increased Residual Volume)

questions.text: A drug with lowest MAC would have the following characteristic_____
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of an inhaled anesthetic is a measure of potency of the anesthetic agent. A drug with the lowest MAC would have the highest potency.

The speed of induction and recovery is indicated by the blood gas partition coefficient.

Least potent: Nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104%. 1MAC with nitrous oxide is practically not possible and thus it is always combined with other agents.

Most potent: Methoxyflurane (MAC- 0.16%) > Trilene (MAC-0.2%), both of which are obsolete now. Among the inhaled agents in clinical use, Halothane is the most potent.
